Award.AbstractNarration:
In a not too distant future, assistive robots will become a natural part of the human society, in hospitals, schools, elder care facilities, inner city urban areas, and eventually homes. While wheeled robots, e.g., a humanoid torso on a mobile platform, can cover a range of tasks that assistive robots will be needed for, eventually, legged robots will be the most suitable, as legs increase the effective workspace of a robot and allow maneuvering more complex terrains like steps, curbs, and cluttered and rough terrains in general.
This project investigates biped locomotion with a Sarcos humanoid robot. In contrast to most other projects in biped locomotion, it emphasizes walking over uneven and rough terrain, obstacle avoidance, recovery from unexpected perturbation, and learning methods for motor control, as these issues seem to be the most important for working in dynamic and partially unpredictable human environments. Another focus is on dexterous movement control, i.e., control with a maximal amount of compliance and minimal negative feedback gains, using advanced operational space controllers with internal model control. Dexterous, compliant control will increase safety of the robot when accidentally impacting with humans or obstacles, and it will also allow the robot to recover more easily from external perturbation simply by ?giving in?. Such a control approach requires departing from the traditional high-gain position controlled humanoid systems, and focuses on torque control, reactive instantaneous control instead of finite horizon optimization, as well as efficient motion planning and learning methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a not too distant future, assistive robots will become a natural part of the human society, in hospitals, schools, elder care facilities, inner city urban areas, and eventually homes. While wheeled robots, e.g., a humanoid torso on a mobile platform, can cover a range of tasks that assistive robots will be needed for, eventually, legged robots will be the most suitable, as legs increase the effective workspace of a robot and allow maneuvering more complex terrains like steps, curbs, and cluttered and rough terrains in general.

This project investigated biped locomotion and learning control with a Sarcos legged humanoid robot and several other robot platforms. Among the most important topics of our research was to create novel solutions to locomotion and control that create compliant control, i.e., control that allows robots to give in when impacting with an obstacle (an object, but also other robots or humans). Such control methods are crucial if robots are going to share the normal environment of humans. The project resulted in a large number of technical contributions to robot control and learning. Among the most salient are novel optimization techniques that enabled our humanoid robot to have very robust balancing and locomotion performance while remaining compliant, and to realize computational methods that can generate such performance in real-time. Another line of research developed learning methods that can learn from simple rewards how to improve motor skills, and that can learn compliant controllers automatically. A bigger theme of our research became how to process large amounts of data generated by the robot’s sensors and incorporate this information into intelligent decision making for control. Novel machine learning techniques were developed to enable such autonomous decision making. As a final result, we have now a novel control and learning software system that works on three different robot platforms and that includes all of our research results in a coherent system architecture for humanoid robot control.
